Hi. We can now start to look at this bug. Can you upload the data set to the NR ftp server?

We have added that if a Crava can't recognize the file-type for seismic, it will try to read it as SegY (but with a warning).

However, when trying to read the cube above (Near15_RP14.sgy) we get the following error in Crava:
"In trace number 0: Different sampling densities given. Initial sampling density of 4ms changed to 5 in trace with XL 2500 and IL 1500."

Looks like the 4ms is taken from the BinaryHeader and the 5ms from the TraceHeader. Does this sound familiar given the current segy-file? And is this the kind of check you suggest we should consider to remove?

The estimated background model on segy format will follow the same shift as input segy (see file for an example). Have tested to run Crava with its own background model, and it was ok.
![cra_793_figure](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4331152/14852660/f871fe66-0c87-11e6-8372-a6ea5d206e9e.png)
We can start to look at this bug if you provide a data set to NR ftp server.
[CRA-794](https://jira.nr.no/browse/CRA-794)

Thanks. The first thing I can see is that the file 'constant1500.txt' is not the proper ascii-format. Crava requires the file to have 5 columns (X, Y, Z, IL and XL), each with a header. This file only has three columns and no header.
The (current) error message 'Did not recognize file as a multicolumns ascii file' is not very constructive..
Can you provide the data case for this issue @RainerTonn? (I don't think we have received it yet).

The xml-file "BDN_Nov16_LSdir.xml" does not match the data in the input-folder. The "BDN_Nov16.xml" file almost matches the input-files (ex. xml file says "Mid_78_81.sgy" and input folder has file "Mid78_81_2s5s.sgy").

Using "BDN_Nov16.xml" (with updated names) we get a 'Segmentation Fault'-error, but that was due to an error when reading Near78_81_2s5s.sgy:
"_There is a region between the base surface of the inversion interval and the seismic data volume with no seismic data. The largest gap is for the seismic trace at position (842048,5316951) where the surface z-value = 3888.09 while the seismic end time = 3004.00. Please include more seismic data or heighten the base surface 884.09ms._"

Does this sounds familiar? Can you take a look at the segy-data?

We will update Crava so the user gets this message and not the 'segmentation fault'-error. However, this isn't the bug in question..
https://jira.nr.no/browse/CRA-796
https://jira.nr.no/browse/CRA-837
https://jira.nr.no/browse/CRA-822
This is fixed.
Ragnar has started looking at this issue. There was some missing data. We received those today.

This should be ok. We have fixed a bug related to this issue. We have tested a case (from Flesche with <segy-start-time>1900) where we first estimated BG and wrote it to file (segy) and then reran the case where we used the estimated BG files as input. This worked.
Issue now ok. We have added support for ascii files and constant values for wavelet intervals.
This is ok, was related to #228.

I have tried to run a few versions of this case:

Case1:
- If I run with <interval-one-surface> and with thickness 500, there was a small bug (with and without <correlation-direction>). We have fixed this and this now runs ok.

Case2:
- When I ran with <interval-two-surfaces> with <correlation-direction> (like the attached xml) I found a bug with estimation of prior-correlations. We have fixed this (but not checked in), and updated with an error message: "There is not enough well data for estimation of prior correlations. For estimation of prior correlations at least 100 blocks are needed; currently there are 58. Either increase the number of layers or add wells."

I have tried to increase the number of layers (to 30), and it worked.

Case3:
- If I run <interval-two-surfaces> without <correlation-direction> I get an error message:
  -Error with top/bottom grids. Minimum thickness should be at least 0.41 times maximum, it is 0.338951.

This is due to the issue with the surfaces (as you mentioned). One solution is to add correlation-direction (which leads to Case2).
Decreasing area size (e.g. setting <xl-end> to 6300), instead of adding correlation-direction, also works (but this will also lead to the prior-correlation issue in Case2).
Ok, we will then change Crava to allow SegY cubes with sampling rates of 1, 2 or 4 ms in BinaryHead. If there are inconsistencies we will give a warning and add the issue to the task list.

Hello,

I tried to read your wells (added them in a different project), and both read without error.
But that was with Crava 4.0, and from the screenshot it looks like you are using an old version of Crava (3.0 / CRAVA_MONCO2-branch)?

There are two main branches of Crava, "CRAVA_MONCO2" and "master".

The "master"-branch is the main branch and the one that contains the multizone-inversion. This is also the branch that we keep developing on (like the fixes we did before the summer).
The "CRAVA_MONCO2"-branch is a branch that hasn't received any development for the last two years, but it contains some functionality that the master-branch misses like 4D inversion and gravimetric-inversion.

I see however that both branches produces a "C R A V A  -  4.0.0 beta" in the logfile (I thought MONCO2 had a 3.0 label).

When we look at the logfile you sent, it looks like a logfile that is produced by the "CRAVA_MONCO2"-branch. Are you deliberately on this branch?

[CRA-825](https://jira.nr.no/browse/CRA-825)
While this is open-ended, there have been several updates regarding logging throughout this project.

Ok, then I misunderstood the problem, sorry. Crava doesn't use the offset information in the traceheader of the cube (for reading or writing). When it reads the segy-cubes it uses the offset given in the modelfile. We will look into this now and try to add the information to all the written cubes. A warning to the users if the input segy offset in different from what is given in the modelfile would also be useful.
The fix is checked in now.
This is checked in.

Regarding writing segy-cubes with offset in traceheader. If there are no segy-cubes (forward model / estimation mode) is it reasonable to take offset from the top of the topsurface of the interval the estimation is done in?

Ok, we can add a <segy-start-time> under <format> (where you specify output <segy>as the output format) that will be used for written segy cubes.
-If this keyword is not given, we will use start-time of input segy.
-If both are omitted we can use top of topsurface.

This is now checked in. Written segy could will now be written with offset, and using <segy-start-time> is optional when reading segy cubes from file.
We have also added the <segy-start-time>-keyword under <grid-output> <format>, which can be used to write segy-files with offset when there are no segy-cubes available (e.g. forward modelling/estimation mode).

Sorry, I forgot the "\" before the tags, so they got lost.  The new tag is the <segy-start-time>

It is as follows:
<grid-output>
--<format>
----<storm> yes <\storm>
----<segy> yes <\storm>
----<segy-start-time> 2000 <\segy-start-time>

This segy-start-time-value is used for writing of segy-cubes. It has to start above the top surface, and it will add padding between the start time and the top of the surface.

If this tag isn't given, the default is to take this segy-start-time from the input seismic data (either from the <segy-start-time> given in <survey> for input data, or if that keyword isn't given it is taken from the traceheader of the seismic segy cubes).
The purpose of this new tag is mainly to add offset to written segy-cubes if you do not have seismic data (like forward modelling).
Howerever, if you do not have seismic data, and do not give <segy-start-time> under <grid-output> will use offset from the top of the top surface.

Tried to run this case without <segy-start-time> (offset taken from the files). The seismic data read fine and I get the following logging:

```
 UTMx         UTMy        IL    XL   Offset   Samples   dt(ms)  Length(ms)
```

---

495956.00   6719999.00           2000  1608     **1900**       376     4.00     1500.00

Using offset 1900 taken from trace header.

Crava crashed when reading the background, but I get the following logging:

```
 UTMx         UTMy     CoScal        IL    XL   Offset   Samples   dt(ms)  Length(ms)
```

---

495956.00   6719999.00        1.0      2000  1608        **0**       376     4.00     1500.00

Using offset 0 taken from trace header.

Do you get the same?
We can debug and see why Crava crashes. But the background I used with CravaSimplified (BG_AI_crop.sgy etc) has an offset of 0, while the segy has an offset of 1900.
You are right. This was a bug, this is fixed and checked in now. Please try again the next time you update Crava.

@alfbr there are also two new tags implemented for this issue. It is <location-start-time> under <segy-format>, both under <seismic-data> and <grid-output>. It is used for manually setting the location if it differ from the standard format, similar to the other <location-xx> tags.
Yes, that is correct.

This is related to both. This is a general fix for reading xyz-surfaces, but tested on a simpler case. It is not certain that it fixes both these problems, so please re-run both cases when this pull-request is merged.

Sorry. This was not merged (this was only a request for merging), so you did not have the updates. (There is usually a small delay from when a request is made to when it is merged into the master branch.)

I have merged the commit into the master branch now. Can you test again tomorrow?
Ah, okey :) I didn't think of that option. Then these issues are still unresolved.
There is a requirement for the surfaces to have an even sampling and it looks like this ML_SimsorXYZ surface has an uneven surface. We have for now added an error message if this happens.

This isn't missing values, but uneven number of points/irregular grid. This is the part of the code where we read the surfaces before we check if some of the values are missing.

It looks like the surface is something like this,
x  x  x  x  x
x  x  x  x  x  
x  x  xx xx x
x xx xx x x

And this causes problems for the routine that reads the surfaces as we try to fit it into a regular grid/surface.
A fix for this is checked in, and reported ok by Flesche.

We are checking in a fix for this now, see our test in the image below. 
Please verify once the pullrequest (#262) is merged.

issues.title: Import of XYZ_Il_Xl horizons
issues.body: I haven't tested horizon import for format XYZIlXl in cases where the survey is not NS-EW oriented. I have such a case here, and the geometry of the inversion becomes all wrong. I compared the input and output surfaces in RMS, and as the ilustration shows they seem to be transposed, but in addition the time scale is also wrong. I have a hard time understanding this, as the format should be the same as that which was tested on OseEast last year.

issue_comments.body:
[background_base_conform.pptx](https://github.com/CRAVA/crava/files/167106/background_base_conform.pptx)
This files illustrates the sharp lateral changes that can come when base or top conform correlation structures are used to create background models. A proportional model would be preferrable, but as discussed there can be limitations in the FFT.

I have made a test where the input background models and the input seismic data both have start at 1900 ms (given in trace header byte 109-110, and also with <segy-start-time>1900</segy-start-time>. Background files saved by Crava does not have a time offset in trace header, and neither do the inversion results or the saved seismic (synthetics/residuals). The saved files should all have the time offset stored in the trace headers.
@alfbr,  @hgolsen: Test results ready regarding the issue. Still open.

The ideal in that case would be that the user sets a fixed time limit for start time, but lacking that the top of the top surface is a reasonable guess. Normally you would wish to have some padding in addition, e.g. half of the wavelength.

Attempted to run CravaSimplified.xml, both as it has been run earlier and with the time taken from the trace header. As I understand it, if the <segy-start-time> is not included in the xml-file and all inputs are consistent in the value in header position 109-110, than Crava will understand the seismic time offset. The latter case gives core dump. Please test and debug @hgolsen

I have re-checked the background AI file, and it seems to be in line with the rest. The traces have a time offset of 1900 ms, and there are no deviating traces reported in the RokDoc segy import, see attachment.
[SEGY time offset.pptx](https://github.com/CRAVA/crava/files/451907/SEGY.time.offset.pptx)
Re-ran test today to check that segy header gets assigned the time start value. Works according to expectations! More exotic variants will not be checked, so I reckon the issue can be closed.

By closer examination of the case it seems that the error message was slightly misleading. We have examined the logs and removed parts with outliers. There was also a case of formatting the wavelets that are used. The header from RokDoc is not accepted by Crava, and a manual editing has to be done. We are now able to run through an "estimation" action without any scaling of the wavelets from RokDoc, and S/N values are acceptable.

issues.title: Extrapolation of surfaces
issues.body:
Surfaces that are eroded, or for other reasons do not cover the whole inversion area needs to be extrapolated. Having crava do this in an automatically would be very convenient. For this to be practical, we need
- Appropriate warning messages
- A clear understanding of minimum requirements for the surface before extrapolation can take place
- A good choice of extrapolation method

issues.title: Interpolation of surfaces
issues.body: Missing values in surfaces can be handled much more generally than today. Ideally, crava should be able to fill in any missing value in a surface by interpolation.

issue_comments.body:
The problem is that the test-suite fills up disk space. We are doing automated builds nightly using a Jenkins server, and all build files are put under /tmp (which means local disk, which in a corporate setting means very cheap and very fast). However, there is not enough room for the test-suite to reside on /tmp, and frankly it is not very practical either (no back-up for instance, it is to be considered as a scratch disk).

Do you think you can help us implement support for having the test-suite in a custom location?

OK, I have done a first attempt to track why static linking fails on Ubuntu. This was on a box running 13.04. The first issue is that the location of the libraries are different, instead of /usr/lib64, the 64-bit libraries are positioned in /usr/lib. Sorting that out, it seems there is a bug related to static linking of these libraries, found here:
http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=354463
I tried the work-around suggestion in the report, but then I had linking issues with gfortran.

Hence, right now my feeling is that we should do to different builds. Static linking for Red Hat and dynamic linking for any other distro (assuming people running other distros are able to install dependencies, which we could cater to with packaging of course). Not sure how easy this is to accommodate in the make file, maybe using the build types is the easiest (e.g., release, debug, etc), having one for dynamic linking and one for static linking? What do you think Pål?

The problem with Red Hat is as I said dependencies. Atlas is not installed by default, and we had one frustrated user just last week. Users cannot be bothered with dependencies, and it is not realistic to have atlas installed on every node. Moreover, we need to distribute it with binaries (i.e., not through rpms which can handle dependencies). Hence, either we have to host the dynamic libraries on network disks and set-up environment variables for library path (which is a hassle in itself), or we need to link statically (in which case the binaries just works on any node).

We did try the static option to gcc (which worked nicely before). However, pthread gave errors preventing the code from running, so this is not really an option. Ulrich Drepper had long rants about static linking and why he did not like it. The Linux standard base basically dictates that a number of libraries should be linked dynamically, most notable glibc (for which Ulrich was responsible for a number of years), while libraries that cannot be expected on hosts should be linked statically.

Long story short, the most practical solution for Red Hat is linking Atlas statically, while linking the rest dynamically, just like we set it up when Marit and myself tried to get this working smoothly over here. What worked for years before did not have multi-threading (no pthread) and statically linking applied to the Intel libraries (which is the typical modus of operandi for Intel libs), things are different today, for the better I hope.

Consider having smooth Red Hat set-up the default build option, rather than treating it as a corner case needing odd command line parameters fed to make.
It compiles on just about any linux distribution. Make sure you have Atlas development libraries installed before you run make as the readme file suggests. I have tested on Red Hat, Ubunu and Debian.

Unfortunately freeing datasets and creating tutorials are typically resource consuming tasks. I am not aware of any effort to provide it. Maybe you want to share your interest in Crava, and what you would like to accomplish? Feel free to pop a mail to either of us if you prefer sharing in private.

The error message is very vague. I believe CRAVA actually supports one missing point in a surface, but not two neighbouring points missing. It seems you will throw regardless with this patch?
Thank you! Closing.

On 05/23/2013 09:33 AM, Lars Vingli Odsæter wrote:

> Hi CRAVA developers!
> 
> I am currently testing CRAVA on Statoil's workstations (RH5 and RH6). I
> have succesfully built CRAVA on both, but are encountering some problems
> with running the test suite. According to the README file it should be
> possible to run the test suite from the test directory itself:
> 
> | How to use the test suite: |
> | --- |
> 
> 1) From directory above  : make test
> 2) From current directory: ./TestScript.pl path-to-executable/cravarun

Yes, this is right.

> This is a nice feature as we don't have to copy the test suite directory
> (which is quite large) to all build realizations. However, when I call
> |./TestScript.pl path-to-executable/cravarun|, I get the following error
> message:
> 
> |Cannot open dir '../src': No such file or directory
> Cannot open dir '../libs/lib': No such file or directory
> Cannot open dir '../libs/boost': No such file or directory
> Cannot open dir '../findgrammar': No such file or directory
> Cannot open dir '../libs/nrlib/eclipsegrid': No such file or directory
> ...
> |
> 
> It seems like |./TestScript.pl| assumes that its parent directory is the
> source directory.
> - Should it be possible to run the test suite out-of-source?

This is currently not possible.

> - If yes; Why does it fail for me?
> - If no; Is it possible to implement this feature? (This will save
>   some memory)

I think all developers have the test suite directory as a subdirectory 
of the CRAVA source directory itself. I see no advantage in having it
differently. Could you please elaborate a bit more about your request
and why you want the test suite outside the source? Are you, for
instance, having more than one source checked out?

Pål

I'll fix.

Pål

> The problem is that the test-suite fills up disk space. We are doing
> automated builds nightly using a Jenkins server, and all build files are
> put under /tmp (which means local disk, which in a corporate setting
> means very cheap and very fast). However, there is not enough room for
> the test-suite to reside on /tmp, and frankly it is not very practical
> either (no back-up for instance, it is to be considered as a scratch disk).

> in a custom location?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/CRAVA/crava/issues/12#issuecomment-18335531.

I fixed this yesterday. Update the test suite from repository
and change line 1509 of TestScript.pl from

my $sourcedir = "..";

to

my $sourcedir = "/path/to/crava/src";

and you should be good to go.

Pål

Unfortunately, I haven't been able to look deeply into this.
The current setup works on RH5, RH6, and Ubuntu for us, and
has worked for some years, I think. And as far as I know, we
have no special RH setup. It's out of the box ... So I
cannot reproduce your problems. But, would it help you to
add the -static flag while linking?  It used to be there
but someone has removed it.

If that's not working we could make a quick-fix like:

ATLASLFLAGS = -L/usr/lib64/atlas -L/usr/lib64/atlas/atlas -L/lib64 
-llapack -lblas -lcblas -latlas -lgfortran -lpthread

ifeq ($(place),statoil)
   ATLASLFLAGS = -L/lib64 -lgfortran -lpthread 
-Wl,/usr/lib64/atlas/liblapack.a,/usr/lib64/libblas.a,/usr/lib64/atlas/libcblas.a,/usr/lib64/atlas/libatlas.a
endif

so that you compile with 'make place=statoil'

On 07/04/2013 03:35 PM, Alf Birger Rustad wrote:

> OK, I have done a first attempt to track why static linking fails on
> Ubuntu. This was on a box running 13.04. The first issue is that the
> location of the libraries are different, instead of /usr/lib64, the
> 64-bit libraries are positioned in /usr/lib. Sorting that out, it seems
> there is a bug related to static linking of these libraries, found here:
> http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=354463
> I tried the work-around suggestion in the report, but then I had linking
> issues with gfortran.
> 
> Hence, right now my feeling is that we should do to different builds.
> Static linking for Red Hat and dynamic linking for any other distro
> (assuming people running other distros are able to install dependencies,
> which we could cater to with packaging of course). Not sure how easy
> this is to accommodate in the make file, maybe using the build types is
> the easiest (e.g., release, debug, etc), having one for dynamic linking
> and one for static linking? What do you think Pål?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/CRAVA/crava/pull/22#issuecomment-20477358.

If you've got Visual Studio available, you can also use
Windows. The project files you need are included in
the project.

Best regards
Pål

From: ganpan [mailto:notifications@github.com]
Sent: 29. oktober 2013 14:50
To: CRAVA/crava
Subject: [crava] wavelet length estimated too long (#47)

I have observed in some cases the CRAVA estimated too long wavelet than what we expected. The default wavelet length in CRAVA is 200ms. And the CRAVA estimated wavelet should usually be close to 200ms. But there are some cases CRAVA estimate wavelets which are as long as 2000ms. It will easily end to an abortion because there are usually no wells have such long continuous logs.

—
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/CRAVA/crava/issues/47.

Hi
It is not easy to see from this log-file that there is a problem that the wavelet length is too long.

What I see related to the wavelet estimation which is strange is  the output is:

Settings for AVO stack 1:
Angle : 7.0
SegY start time : 0.0
Data : 06near16.segy
Estimate wavelet : yes
Signal-to-noise ratio : 2.8

It seems that you want CRAVA to estimate the wavelet, but not the signal to noise ratio. Which you fix at 2.8.
If this is the case this is not a good practice. If you want to run CRAVA with an estimated wavelet and a given
Signal to noise ratio,  you should run CRAVA in estimation mode, to get the Estimated wavelets and then use these
wavelets as input to the model, together with a fixed signal to noise ratio.
(You do the same for several stacks)

Odd

Sent: 29. oktober 2013 14:50
To: CRAVA/crava
Subject: [crava] wavelet length estimated too long (#47)

I have observed in some cases the CRAVA estimated too long wavelet than what we expected. The default wavelet length in CRAVA is 200ms. And the CRAVA estimated wavelet should usually be close to 200ms. But there are some cases CRAVA estimate wavelets which are as long as 2000ms. It will easily end to an abortion because there are usually no wells have such long continuous logs.

I suspect there is a HRS issue. The original file was a 5m sampled PSDM which I converted to a 4ms time sampled time version. With the contradiction in the header information it is hard to decide what is correct. However, CRAVA is supposed to be run on time seismic. Therefore I suggest:
If CRAVA encounters a sampling problem it should pops up with a warning asking the user if the input is time. If the input is time, only sampling rates like 1ms, 2ms and 4ms should be accepted and if this SR is in the binary header it should be accepted.
